div.head: RENTS AND TRAMWAYS.
div.p: While rents in Alexandria have, during the last few years, shown a rising tendency in every direction,-perhaps oly commensurate with the growing prosperity of the city, and therefore not to be wondered at,-in one suburb, that of Ibrahimieh, this increase has assumed such proportions as to render it almost impossible to obtain a small house there at such rent as the man with a limited income can afford to pay. The reason of this is not far to seek. Ibrahimieh lies high and is a remarkably healthy place; the service of electric tramcars permits of its being easily reached from the business quarter of Alexandria; and its proximity to both the sea and the open country renders it a desirable place of residence and attractive in the extreme. It is therefore not surprising that houses should be much sought for in this quarter, not on the other hand that rents should show a great increase. Landlords are alike the world over, and are the last people in the world to neglect their opportunities. It rests with the public authorities to prevent as far as possible an abuse of such opportunities as those of which the owners of property at Ibrahimieh are just now, it appears tous, taking a very unfair advantage, demanding as they do a rental not in any respect warranted by the accomodation offered, and only obtained consequently on supply being unequal to demand. A case has come under our own notice of a house of two stories built some years ago and formerly let at 20 per annum. Now a staricase has been run up to the upper floor, so inconveniently built as to render it impossible

for a piano to be taken through the confined space in which it is erected, and the house let to two tenants the occupier of the ground floor paying 30 while the upper floor is in for 36. House and ground probably cost much less than 100 altogether in the fine instance, and nothing but the extreme scarcity of accommodation can account for the realness of tenants to submit to such extortions and demands. Compared with this the raising of rents 20, 25, and even more per cent., of which we hear on all hands, seems moderate. Houses, too, are being built upon every corner of the garden or scrap of land available for the purpose, and it continues for long, a few years will real district overcrowded and unhealthy instead of as at present, roomy and healthy. Meantime, just as near to the city but just too far from the tramway line to offer necessary advantages in the matter of time an equally extensive area of ground capable of development at the hands of the builders and to make this land available all that is required is the extension of the tramway service along the Ramleh road from the point at which it turns off in the direction of Ramleh Point to Sidi Gaber, or as an alternative establishment of a local service of trains from Sidi Gaber, calling at Hadra and running in intervals of a few minutes during the long hours of the day. As regards the tramway, learn that the Municipality is as yet undecided as to whether it shall allow the Ramleh Company to remain on the portion of the ground, forming the new quay on which it now returns or requres it to return to the old routes to make use of the former site of the terminality. But this question may be left quite outside that of the extension of the city services to Sidi Gaber or Hadra, except in so far as that it increased traffic on the line would render the running of the Ramleh cars through the Rue de Ramleh a matter of impossibility. Such an arrangement, we believe, has been comtemplated, or at any rate suggested. We should be sorry to see it tried, even as an experiment. One objection may fairly be urged again in the extension at the presernt time of the tramway system, and that is that the need for it in a future and not a present one. This is so, and there is no reason whatever why, as is with respect to the Abbassieh Oasis at Cairo, the building of houses and the making of the tramway line should not proceed simultaneously. Will not some public company acquire a sufficiently large parcel of land and guarentee the erection of a suficient number of houses to warrant the making of the line? Cooperation in such a matter is essential. There can be a manner of doubt that the building of a number of flats suited to the requirements of business man of limited income, in which one could reside with the certainty that he would be free from the rapacity of the private landlord (knowing that the shareholders of a company would be in the main men who are content with a fair return for their investments would prove highly beneficial and popularly measure and one which would well repay can outlay. Block of buildings might be erected would be common to all, as is the one in many of the London squares at once affecting ground for recreation and a guarentee against encroachment in the future. This question of rents is a serious one, especially when considered in connection with the rising prices of food; and the provisions suitable accommodation for the residents of the city, and especially for those who cannot build or buy houses for themselves, and engage the attention of the Municipality quay as much as the erection of fine buildings in the new quay. We have that all facilities be given for the opening up of the H district. It appears to us an excellent way of checking the practices of which we compare at Ibrahimieh, and which, if counted, may result ere long in producing a very understandable state of affairs in that suburb of the country.

div.head: Holidays.
div.p: The Ministries and administrations will be closed from to-morrow to Wednesday next, inclusive, for the Kourban-Beyram holidays.

div.head: Military Tournament Postponed.
div.p: The military tournament which should have taken place at Ghezireh yesterday was postponed on account of the death of the King of Denmark.
Land Allotment Co.
Hassan Pacha Assem has purchased from the El Daraumlie family, on behalf of the Anglo-Egyptian Land Allotment Company, 1,180 teddans at Menchiet-el-Ibrahimieh for L. E. 64,000.
Moslem Benefit Performance.

Toe performance in aid of the E' Orwa el Woska Benevolent Society will take place at the Zizinia Theatre on Thursday, 8th inst., when Shekri Ganem's Antar will be produced. H.H. the Khedive will honour the performance with his presence.
Postal Innovation.

From today, all letters, newspapers, etc., which bear fall addresses, will be delivered to the houses and offices of the addresses in Cairo and Alexandria by postmen. It will therefore no longer be necessary to make special applications for this privilege.
A Daira Sanieh Case.

Yesterday the case brought by Sayed Evida and partners against the Daira Sanieh and other defendants came before the Second Civil Chamber of the Cairo Mixed Courts. The action is brought by the inhabitants of the village at Armant factory, numbering 4,000 persons, because the Daira sold the entire village.
Bank of Egypt.

The directors recommend a dividend of 10 per cent. for the year ended December 31 (of which an interim dividend of 4 per cent. was paid on July 15 last), also a bonus of 20s. per share, together 18 per cent. for the year— as compared with 16 per cent. for the year 1904 leaving 14,655 (after adding 40,000 to the reserve) to be carried forward to the next account.
Clever Capture of Smugglers.
On Wednesday, a small Coast Guard patrol saw a five-oared native boat in the distance, and as it did not stop when hailed, gave chase.

The boat went alongside one of the Steamers and the crew bolted, leaving their boat, which was found to contain a cargo of about a quarter of a ton of hashish. Three of the smugglers were seized as they were leaving the steamer by the Customs Guards, who had been attracted to the spot by the alarm signals of the Coast Guard patrol boat.
Revue d'Egypte et d'Orient.

This excellent little publication has now reached its seventh year, which, we are inclined to think, constitutes a record for publications of the kind in Egypt. The success of the review, however, is well-merited, and in the capable editorial hands of M. Fernand Braun its continued success should be assured. The January number is as interesting as its predecessors, and contains among other things part
of the fourth and the whole of the fifth act of M. Shekri Ganem's successful play Antar.
Egyptian Arabic

A second edition of Judge Willmore's hand-book of spoken Egyptian Arabic has made its appearance. In this new edition there are considerable improvements. The vocabulary has been enlarged and a few useful phrases added also to illustrate the structure of the language. A short story ("The Ill-treated Burglar") is given in Arabic with a word-for-word translation and references to the rules of grammar. This manual contains a summary grammar of the Arabic language, as spoken by the natives of Cairo, and a vocabulary of English words in common use, with their Arabic equivalents. If a careful study is made of the few pages comprising the former, it will be found possible to so use the vocabulary as to obtain a store of expressions sufficient for ordinary needs. Where an English word omitted, some other, bearing a similar sense to it, will generally be found. Those who wish to make a more serious study of the grammar are referred to the author's "Spoken Arabic of Egypt."
The first edition of 1,000 copies has sold out very satisfactorily for a book of this kind.
Anglo-Egyptian Automatic Co.

Yesterday week at the Mansion House Stuart Dixon Stubbs Ross, 38, of Thicket-road Anerley, and George Bertram Ross, 35, of the same address, general merchants, underwent a final examination before Sir Horatio Davies, charged with an alleged conspiracy to obtain by false pretences moneys and securities from persons who might be induced to become
shareholders in the Anglo-Egyptian Automatic Trading Company (Limited), and, further, with obtaining from Mr. J. G. Prentice, a Liverpool insurance agent, the sum of £525 15s. 6d.

Stuart Ross was charged also with obtaining the sum of £648 7s. 6d. from Mr. John Champneys, shipowner, of Hans-place. The facts of the case have been fully reported in our columns. In reply to the statutory caution Stuart Ross said : "I had no intention of defrauding anybody. My brother acted entirely as my clerk in the correspondence, and had no interest whatever in the proceeds of the shares that were sold." George Ross said, "I plead not guilty." Both men were committed for trial at the Central Criminal Court which opens on February 5, bail being allowed.

div.head: PROSPECTIVE PUBLIC WORKS.
"BACK TO THE LAND" MOVEMENT
div.p: I understand that the chief public works to be undertaken in the Sudan during the course of the present year are the preliminary works in connection with the construction of the Nile bridges at Khartoum and the new line of railway to Kassala.

A labour bureau is in course of formation at Port Sedan, and the system will in all probability be extended if so required. Contractors are paying high wages to labourers at Port Sudan and the result is that this is drawing men away from agricultural and other forms of industry in the Valley of the Nile. The Government wishes to chock this tendency.

div.head: THE SUCRERIES.
div.p: The National Association of French Holders of Foreign Stock has addressed a circular to the bondholders of the Société des Sucieries d'Egypte (Egyptian Sugar Refineries Company), describing the principal proposals for a settlement, which will be submitted to the meeting to be held on February 10. No modifications of these proposals will be allowed. Among the chief features is the exchange of the present bonds for new ones giving a variable return, these bonds being of a nominal value of 400f., capable of bearing a maximum interest of 20f. and redeemable at 500f. while interest at the rate of 8f. per annum is to be guaranteed for three years- from 1906 to 1909 -in the case of bondholders who renounce all claims against the directors or it third parties.

div.head: ANCIENT LIGHTS AT CAIRO.
div.p: A curious lawsuit is coming before the Cairo Mixed Courts shortly. The sons of Tigraine Pacha have built a wall which shuts off the light and intercepts the north wind from the New Khédivial Hotel at Cairo. The proprietor of this hotel is the plaintiff in the case.

div.head: DISTRICT POST OFFICES.
div.p: The Postal Administration has decided upon the opening of new branch post offices in the following localities which are comprised in the Cairo postal district, viz., at Bab-el Khalk, Old Cairo, and Marg. The first two will be opened on the 1st March, whilst the latter opens to-day, and all three offices will be admitted to ail branches of the service. Postal business at Old Cairo is at present transacted in connection with the local telegraph office, but it is decided to discontinue this arrangement and from the 1st proximo to have a post office separately from the telegraph service. No sanction has been yet given by the Finance Ministry for branch office in the Ismailieh quarter.

A parcels office has also been established at the Cairo Custom House for the clearing of parcels from all countries. Hitherto the clearing of P.O. parcels in Cairo had been confined to those arriving from the United Kingdom only.

div.head: CAIRO MARRIAGE DISSOLVED.
div.p: Lieut. Col. C.R. Haggard, brother of Mr. H. Rider Haggard, who was married in Cairo in 1883 to Miss Emily Chirnside, has just obtained a divorce in America, alleging desertion.

div.head: YESTERDAY'S GARDEN PARTY.
LARGE & REMARKABLE GATHERING.
div.p: The garden party given by Sir Reginald and Lady Wingate in the Palace grounds this afternoon was a great success. Among the large party present were Lord Cromer, Mr. Vincent Corbett, Sir R. Slatin Pacha, Miralai Stanton Bey, Colonel Bernard, Bimbashi Owen, Kaimakan Asser, Miralai Macanley, Mr. Currie, Sir. Bonham-Carter, besides all the principal officials and officers, the invited members of the Legislative Council, the Roman Catholic Bishop of Central Africa, the ulema of Khartoum, the chief members of the Greek, Italian, and Syrian communities, the Coptic and Maronite bishops, Zubeir Pacha, Sheikh Hassan, Grand Cadi of the Sudan, Sheikh Dai, Grand Mufti of the Sudan, Sheikh Ismain, Cadi of Khartoum, Sheikh Khudan, head Arabic professor of the Gordon College, Sheikh Taib, of the Western Arabs, Sheikh Abdelazim, of the Bisharin, Sheikh Wad Saad, of the Jaaliu, Sheikh Morgham, Muhamed Bay Abdallah, Mohamed Bey Hassan, etc. Among the ladies were Mesdames de Halpert, McCracken, Gamble, Bingley, Stanton, Bernard, Asser, Page, Broun, More, Balfour, Shukair, Stack, Feetham, Harvey, the Misses Wilson, Bewley, and Denford, and many more. All seemed to enjoy the function thoroughly. The scene presented was brilliant in the extreme, and one not soon to be forgotten, owing to the associations of the place where it was held, and also to the remarkable contrasts presented by the many and varied costumes of those present. Lord Cromer leaves Khartoum to-night unofficially and without any ceremony. The train will leave Khartoum North at 10 p.m., arriving at 9 a.m. to-morrow at Zeidab, where Lord Cromer will be met by the Governor of the Berber Province, and will cross to Mr. Leigh Idun's estate on the west bank in the Sudan Government steamer Tahra.

Lord Cromer will, in the afternoon, proceed in the Tahra to Atbara junction, where the train will be waiting, and will leave at 6 p.m. for Halfa, which will be reached at 10.30 a.m. on the 2nd of February.

div.head: FESTIVITIES AT ASSOUAN.
div.p: Last night, or rather, last night and this morning, the great event of the year, for Assouan at least, took place i.e., the fancy dress ball at the Cataract Hotel. In the cause of charity Terpsichore held out hands and her feet twinked for Æsculapins, the proceeds of the admission going to the hospital at Luxor.

Many guests from the Savoy and other hotels performers made the best of it; and one dined with friends and as fancy dress was requested the effect was very pretty. It would be well if everyone would remember, so as to avoid repetition, that whenever the moon is "en evideuce" there is always an ideal night here, and going to such an entertainment on a steam launch under the starlit sky with gleams of moonlight shining between the leaves of the palms on Elephantine Island was a fairy-like dream.
The large reception hall was crammed with people, some having come expressly from

Luxor for this particular evening only, while an expression of "happy release" was apparent upon the faces of some few who had been waiting their costumes from Cairo, the train having been as usual (en paranthèse) late, only this time worse than usual, i.e., three hours over her time !
The procession to the great Arabic dining hall took place at about ten o'clock and nothing could exceed the brilliancy of the scene.

There were Pierrots aud Scotchmen, Incroyables and Dragomans ; black and white, one in particular bearing a lable on which was writ "English Spoken, American Understood," a most comic bewhiskered tourist, while Royalty was in a Paladin's chain and steel armour of the Second Crusade time, two knights similarly clad were in close attendance. A German newspaper-clad lady afforded varied but uncertain reading, a Neapolitan peasant, accompanied by the Neapolitan peasant husband, were highly praised. A "Grande Dame" of the Court of Louis XVI., wore her diamonds and her powdered hair with grace and dignity. A charming little Japanese girl was a universally-asked-for partner. It is impossible to catalogue all the pretty dresses and invidious name anyone except perhaps Mr. Pagn n (the managing director of the hotels), whose general presence and hearty manner gave a strong fillip to the entertainment. Dancing to a most charming orchestra, eating and drinking of the best, flirting—but then it was all a beautiful dream and it is all over till next year.

div.head: MR. MACHELL'S VISIT.
STRANGE RAILWAY EXPERIENCES.
div.p: Mr. Machell, Adviser to the Ministry of the Interior, and Lady Victoria Machell are coming here about the 4th proxo. The Adviser is coming on official business and will inspect the district offices.
Major Elgood, the Inspector, will be with the Adviser during his visit to this province.

The Fayoum Light Railway is going from bad to worse. Here is a sample of what the passengers have to put up with. An English resident in the Fayoum was the other day on his way by train from Roda to Medinet el Fayoum in company with a Sanitary inspector and a European contractor. The train kept on stopping and finally came to a standstill between two stations while the locomotive went off leaving the train to take care of itself. The neighbourhood was not remarkable for its security and the omdeh of a village near by sent four armed ghaffirs to protect the passengers and the goods. After a long and weary wait the locomotive came back and managed to draw the train to Adeva station. There the passengers were told that all further progress was impossible owing to the complete lack of coal. The passengers had consequently to shift for themselves.

div.head: A. L. M. & D. S.
div.p: An excellent musical and dramatic entertainment was given by the Alexandria Literary, Musical and Dramatic Society in Lifont's Concert-room on Tuesday evening. The hall was packed with a large and appreciative audience. The programme opened with Grieg's Berceuse (Vuggerise), in G minor, which was well played by Miss Mary Tortello. The swinging rhythm which characterises this piece was perhaps not given all the emphasis it required, but the phrasing of the sixths, in which it abounds, was neat and crisp. A certain lack of precision was noticeable, but this is a defect that increase of years and experience will doubtless remove. Two songs were then sung by a singer whose name is a sufficient guarantee of their performance, and what the audience evidently expected Mrs. Edward Moss gave them. Her second song especially was sung with great dramatic feeling and yet always with the reserve its grand and measured harmonies required. Her songs were perhaps a little above the heads of some of the audience, though they were very well received. The next item was a violin duet, Symphonie Concertante, by Danels, played by Misses. N. and R. Scheratter. It must be confessed that it was not a very interesting or stirring piece, though the performers made the best of it; and one obvious and almost inevitable defect in a duet of violins was occasionally very noticeable, viz., a tendency for the instruments to be out of tune. In spite, however, of these slight discrepancies, the performance on the whole was very good and very much liked by the audience. Mr. Percy Byrne appeared next with M. V. White's "The Devout Lover." We thought he began his song with a slight lack of interest, but as he proceeded he was caught with the spirit of this perhaps most beautiful of all Maud Valeui White's compositions, and his splendid rendering was greeted at the end with tremendous applause. He replied to the demand for an encore with Lambert's "The Sweetest Flower that blows." The last musical item was Mascheroni's "For all Eternity," sung magnificently by Mrs. Edward Moss. It is doubtful if this accomplished singer has ever been heard to better advantage than in this old favourite, and the audience gave ample testimony of their realisation of this fact by the tumultuous applause with which the song was received. Mrs. Moss replied to the incessant demand for another song with Fontanailles' "Obstipation," a French 'suggestion' more than a song, sung with great taste. This concluded the musical part of the programme.

The second part consisted of a farcical comedy in one act by John M. Morton entitled "Whitebait at Greenwich," in which Messrs. Pearce-Hill, H. Dowthwate, M. Blythman, L. Payne, and F. Corfield took the role of the different characters, and kept the house convulsed with laughter as they worked out the imbroglio of the "plot." It was altogether a most happy and deliciously amusing piece and did credit to the performers. It is always an invdion talk to discriminate between amateurs, but we may be permitted to mention the clever way in which both Mr. Payne and Mr. Corfield assumed the female parts. Mr. J. Pearce-Hill is too well-known for his histrionic abilities to need special mention, and he was ably supported by the others.

Altogether the entertainment was a most pleasant one and reflects great credit on the committee, who we believe, met with almost insurmountable difficulties in connection with finding a suitable locale and fixing up a temporary stage. We understand that another concert will be given by the society at an early date.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Ellerman S.S. Bloemontein arrived at Liverpool on Tuesday
Th« Ellerman S.S. City of Venice sailed from Malta last night and is due here on Sunday morning with passengers, mails, and a general cargo.
The Messageries steamer Senegal arrived Marseilles from Alexandria yesterday.

div.head: KOURBAN-BEYRAM.
HOURS AND ORDER OF RECEPTION.
div.p: On the occasion of Kourban Beyram, his Highness the Khedive will hold a reception on Sunday, 4th proxo., at Abdeen Palace, when visitors will observe the following hours and order : —

At 9.30 a.m—Their Highnesses the Princes of the Khédivial Family ; the President of the Council of Ministers and the Ministers ; the Financial Adviser ; the Judicial Adviser; the Adviser at the Ministry of the Interior and of Public Works; the Under Secretaries of State.

At 10 a.m.—The former Presidents of the Council of Ministers, Presidents of the Legislative Council, Sirdars, Grand Masters of Ceremonies, Chiefs of the Khédivial Cabinet, Chief Aides-de-Camp, Directors of the Khédivial Khassa, Directors General of Wakfs, Under Secretaries of State, Directors-General of the Daira Sanieh, Administrators of the State Domains and Administrators of Railways and Telegraphs ; unofficial civil and military personages having the rank of Lewa or Oulaf Sinf Sani and upwards, officers of the Navy and Army on pension or on the retired list, of the rank of Kaimakam or Miralai ; civil Beys not in office, of the rank of Moutemaiz and Sanieh.
At 10.30 a.m.—The Diplomatic and Consular-Corps.
At 10.45 a.m —The Public Debt Commissioners ; the Administrators of State Domains.
At 11 a m.—The field officers of the Army of Occupation ; the Clergy ; the Mixed Magistracy ; the Native Magistracy.

This reception is received to persons resident in Cairo. Decorations will be worn. Naval and Military officers will be in full dress uniform ; natives and foreigners of rank or exercising duties obliging them to wear a special uniform, will wear those uniforms. Native and European officials whose rank or duties do not oblige them to wear a uniform will appear in stambouline, with black trousers. Non-official Europeans and those without rank will wear dress suits. Natives who wear national costume will be received in that costume.

The civil officials to be admited to this reception are those holding at least the rank of sub-director or an equivalent rank, and those holding, at least, the rank of Sanieh or Kaimakam (military) and magistrates appointed by decree
Names may be registered for H.H the Khedivah at the Bureau of Ceremonies of the Harem, beside the Gate of Honour of Abdeen Palace.

RIFLE SHOOTING.

There will be a match on Monday morning next, 5th inst., commencing at 9.30, between teams from the 1st Royal Dublin Fusiliers and the British Rifle Club (Alexandria), eu the Mustapha Pacha range. The B.R.C. (Alexandria) will practise next Saturday afternoon
K.S.C.

Manilla Michaelides, the rider of Tamerlan, and Thomson, the rider of Fil de Fer, were called before the Stewards for foul riding in the Eclipse Stakes on Friday, January 26. Both were suspended from riding till after the conclusion of the K.S.C. Third Winter Meeting.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: The new King of Denmark was born in 1843 and married the daughter of King Carl XVI of Sweden and Norway in 1869. He has eight children, the eldest of which is Prince Christian, born 1870, and married to the Princess Alexandrine of Meckenburg.
Prince Louis and Princess Antoine d'Orleans and Braganza, who have arrived in Cairo and are staying at the Savoy Hotel, are accompanied by Count Charles Chorinsky.

Among others who have arrived recently at the Savoy are Lady and Miss Kitson, Sir Walter Murton, C.B., late solicitor to the Board of Trade, and Miss Morton, Mr. Albert de Goldsebmidt-Rothschild, Mr. C. J. de Guimaracs, M.F., C.B., and Mr. W. E. Bourn, who is so well known in San Francisco.
Lady Chetwode has returned to Cairo from her trip to Upper Egypt.
Mrs. Helène de Weerth has left Cairo for a short trip up the Nile, but is expected back at the Savoy in about a fortnight.
Mr. and Mrs. Truby Williams have left Cairo and are now on their way to Sicily.

div.head:
THE UNIONIST PARTY.
POSSIBILITY OF A SPLIT.
QUESTION OF PARTY LEADERSHIP.

div.p: Considerable attention has been attracted by columns of letters to the Unionist papers on the question of party leadership. Large numbers are in favour of Mr. Chamberlain or urge Mr. Balfour to adopt a bolder policy. The "Times" and "Morning Post" publish tables showing that the complexion of the Opposition is mainly Chamberlainite. (Reuter)

Several rifts are noticeable in the Unionist party. Some demand the abandonment of Fiscal Reforms : others point out that a strong movement is perceptible against the leadership of Mr. Balfour. The possibility of a split-on that question early next session is being discussed.
(Reuter)

div.head:
NEW KING OF DENMARK.
"CHRISTIAN IS DEAD, LONG LIVE FREDERICK."

div.p: Frederick has been proclaimed King by the Premier from the balcony at Amalienborg Palace, shouting "Christian is dead, long live Frederick." The King in a proclamation declares that he will unswervingly maintain the constitution.
The King has marked his accession by granting an amnesty to prisoners. (Reuter)
The British Court has gone into mourning for six weeks. (Reuter)
The Kings of Greece, Norway, and Sweden will attend the funeral. (Reuter)
Four days anti-Jewish rioting has taken place at Homel following the murder of a police official. A portion of the town has been burned. (Reuter)
A gang of vagabonds have pillaged and set fire to the Jewish shops. The discontented C ossaoks took part in the pillage. (Havas)
Armed mobs pillaged the goods station here on Monday, killing the station master. The rabble stormed the chief police station yesterday, liberating a number of political prisoners.
(Reuter)

Signor Fortis has informed the Chamber that the constitution of the Cabinet will not affected by the general policy. It is proposed to meet certain requirements for defence and armaments hitherto deferred owing to want of fonds, but military expenditure will be reduced by proposing a system of two years' enlistment. (Reuter)

div.head:
ALGECIRAS CONFERENCE.
ATTITUDE OF GERMAN DELEGATES.

div.p: The German delegates maintain a Sphinx-like attitude, and refuse to be drawn into any discussion as to their intentions and policy. This, coupled with the dilatory proceedings of the Moors, affords a poor prospect, of an early settlement. (Reuter)

div.head:
FRENCH SEPARATION LAW.
DISTURBANCES IN PARIS CHURCHES.

div.p: The agitation in the provinces against inventorying church chattels under the Separation Law has spread to this city, where there have been disturbances and protests in many churches. (Reuter)
The faithful have prevented the registration inspector from entering most of the churches to make the inventories. (Havas)
The German steamer Sylvia has returned here damaged by striking a mine. ( Reuter )

As an adjunct to their system of electric lighting and ventilating of Railway Carriages we understand that Messrs. J. Stone & Company Limited have invented a system for supplying cooled fresh air (free from dust) to Railway passenger cars. This is a boon which will doubtless be fully appreciated by the travelling public in hot weather, and doubly so in hot climates.

div.head: MONEY AND SHARE MARKET.
div.p: The Elections and the City.

All interest in the elections is now passing away, in view of the fact that no reversal of the general verdict is now possible, and City men are not sorry to see a majority large enough to guarantee the independence of the Irish and Labour parties, and a moderate policy generally. No doubt exists that Mr. Asquith will be able to effect large economies, unless international complications should arise, and the Badgets of the next few years should be favourable not only to the taxpayer bat also to the investor and the money market.

The important feature of the week has been the addresses of the chairmen of the great banks of London. For banks, the past year has been a prosperous one, and there is unanimity in the opinions of these gentlemen who, from Mr. Felix Schuster downwards, are certainly in the best position to give an opinion, that the coming year will show an all round improvement. The turn-over of the Clearing House in 1905 exceeded £12,000,000,000, and it is no wonder that as far as the banking interest is concerned a Free Trade or a Free Import policy is a good one. In the City election Mr. Schuster's candidature fairly represented the interests of banking, but those of the merchant and trader which prevailed were undoubtedly better represented by Mr. Gibbs. That Mr. Balfour should take Mr. Gibbs's place as representative of the intelligent opinion of the "hub" of London is not inappropriate, as we believe that his views on this subject are more largely appreciated in the City than elsewhere. To retain an open mind on the subject of move with the greatest the direction of enlarging pressure on other countries is, considered by the best men in the City the wisest policy to adopt, resigning his seat has performed act, and while the City may gain in having as representative a man of greater position and calibre, they feel that they are losing an old and tried friend.
Gold Reserves.

The subject of gold reserves has again come under discussion, as is usual at this time of year, and while Mr. Schuster's opinion that the Bank should retain larger gold reserves meets with approval, the City wants to know what help the Banks are giving the central institution in this respect. The reserves held at the Bank of England by the various great joint-stock banks are undoubtedly much below what a patriotic view of the situation would demand. The Bank of England occupies a position of very great responsibility, and upon it the whole of the other banking institutions must in the end rely. It is, therefore, clearly their concern, first of all, to see that their accounts with the Bank fairly represent in the matter of gold reserve the huge business they receive. In time of tension, the whole of the banks have to stand by one another, and were a larger reserve deposited by the joint-stock banks it would greatly relieve matters at a time of pressure. There is, however, in the opinion of Mr. Schuster and other great bankers, no prospect of a scarcity of money, providing no unforseen event should occur, and while in the open market money is not particularly plentiful, the large reserves of bullion in America (150,000,000) and France (115,000,000) as well as Germany, must have the effect of relieving pressure on London, where there is every prospect of gold returning.
The Silver Position.

The position of the silver market is creating considerable interest. The extraordinary accumulations under the Sherman Act in the United States have been worked of with great rapidity, chiefly owing to the large payment for subsidiary coinage in the States in these, recent years of great prosperity. For any requirements now the United States has to come into the market During the Russo-Japanese war large quantities of Mexican silver were taken for the use of the troops and based in Manchuria, and this is not expected to return. In the meantime, the production of silver for all purposes remains very steady between £168,000,000 and £170,000,000 ounces per annum. Very large amounts seem to disappear in India and elsewhere, and it does not seem at all improbable that a considerable rise in the price might take place. At present it is quoted at 30 1/8d. per ounce.

In this matter the action of China will be a very important factor, as it appears probable that a very great change is coming over the Chinese nation, leading to extended trade and industry and a consequent enlargement of demand for silver for coinage and other purposes.
Dull Markets.

As regards stocks and shares, there is little to note, as the week has been chiefly spent in a dull, uninteresting settlement, the only real feature of interest being the important dividends of the railway companies. The Lancashire & Yorkshire have had a very prosperous year, and are able to announce a dividend of 4 1/4 per cent. as against 3 3/4 per cent, on the previous occasion. The gross earnings of the G est Central have increased by £132,000, and in addition to paying 3 1/2 per cent. on the Preference stock of 1881 making a fall 5 per cent, for the year, they are distributing 3 1/8 per cent. on the 4 per cent. Preference of 1899. The dividend of the North Eastern is an increase of 1/2 per cent. being 6 1/4 as against 5 3/4. The London and South Western pay the same as for the past three years, viz., 6 per cent. on the

Undivided Ordinary stock and 2 per cent. on the Deferred. The company's profits have expanded by £25,000, but they have adopted the wise course of appropriating this for renewals. The Central London distribution is again 4 per cent. but the appropriation to reserve is less by £20,000 than last time. The Tilbury revenue shows a decrease of £6,260, and the dividend is 7 1/4 per cent. per annum.

While the elections last it is not probable that any great movement will take place on the Stock Exchange, but it is predicted by the most enlightened members of the "House" that the end of the month will see a great change for the better. The assurances of the chairmen of the various banks is likely to encourage this movement, and the uncertainty of the Morocco Conference seems to be the only factor that is holding things back.

With the exception of Egyptian Estates and Nile Valleys, things Egyptian have hardly been mentioned this week, and in the mining market Egyptians have taken a very small place. In mining centres it has been noted with interest that the banket reef, on which are the Tarquah, the Effuenta, and many other of the mining interests of West Africa, has been proved to be richer than that of the Transvaal, and apparently equally reliable. After the severe handling investors in West African shares have experienced in the past few years this confirmation of the substantial value of many of their securities has come as a great relief.
Consols.
Consols are practically unchanged on last Friday's quotation at 89 15/16. Other gilt-edged stocks remain steady.
Foreign Securities.

In this market Japanese have been slightly easier, and Russians have failed to maintain last week's advance. The price of the latter to-night is 88 1/4. Japanese stocks to-night close very fist, the four per cent. being 90, and the new four per cent. 1/2 discount.
Railways.
The announcement of the dividends has imported additional movement to the market for home rails, and the heavy lines have been particularly active. There is every prospect of a boom in this section.
The American railway market has been somewhat irregular for the greater part of the week but a more cheerful tone prevailed to-day, and higher prices were obtained.
Egyptians.

In the Egyptian section, Egyptian Estates have been largely dealt in, and there are a number of buyers about. The price closes either side of 1 1/2. National Banks have kept firm and close 26, and the last issue at 5 1/4 premium. Agricultural Bank of Egypt have advanced to 9 3/4 and the last issue to 9 3/8.

Delta Preference have bean a shade harder at 11 5/8, but could not maintain this figure, and leave off small sellers at 11 1/2. Daira Ordinary and Deferred are quite unchanged at 17 1/2 and 104 respectively, and Union Fancière at 3/8-5/8 premium, and Abyssinian Banks at 1/8-3/8 premium are also unmentioned. Egyptian Markets are nominally 1 5/16 without any business about, but Salt & Soda are a fraction better at 1 1/16 buyers. Daira Sugar are 4 5/8, and Khédivial Mail are 1 1/4-1/2, the Preference shares of the latter company have been enquired for at 4 3/4.
Mining.
There appears still to be much uneasiness in the South African market respecting the Government's probable policy as regards that country, and this is reflected in the lower prices of shares.
In the Egyptian section Nils Valleys have been largely dealt in, and the price has advanced to 9/-. The other Egyptian shares have not been mentioned.
The closing prices to-night are as follows :—

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET
Kearsley and Cunningham's Weekly Report.
div.p: An extensive business has bean done in Egyptian Cotton this week, the demand, however, has been freely supplied. Quotations are raised 1/16 per lb. for Fair Brown and Fine Upper, whilst all other qualities are 1/8 per lb. dearer. In Futures a good business has also been done and the following are the latest values :—
Jany. 8 8 Apl. 8.10 July 8.9
Feby. 8.9 May 8.10 Aug. 8 9
Mch. 8.10 June 8.10 Nov. 7.44

AMERICAN FUTURES. The Market this week has again displayed considerable activity both for Spot Cotton and for Deliveries, and prices have fluctuated widely. An advance of 14 @ 15 points has been followed by a fall of 20 @ 21 points, to-day's closing values being 6 @ 7 points below those of last Thursday. The National Ginners, Report and the Bureau Census Ginners, Report have been awaited with a certain amount of anxiety, but both have come and gone, and as far as the Market is concerned, have made very little lasting impression. The Bureau Report estimated the amount ginned from 1st to 16th January at 277,000 bales, whereas the National dinners only estimated the amount at 176,000 bales : this latter report may at once be dismissed and the Bureau Census Report is generally accepted, and is supposed to indicate a yield of from 10 1/2 to 11 millions. This seems an ample supply taking the visible and invisible stocks into account, and that the price of the article is 6d per lb. Interest will very shortly concentrate itself upon the area to be planted, and the weather conditions prevailing.
The latest quotations are, delivery:-
Jany. 5.99 Apl/May 6.05 Aug/Sept. 6.03
Jan/Feby 5.99 May/June 6.07 Sept/Oct 5.79
Feby/Mch 5.99 June/July 6.09 Oot/Nov. 5.71
Mch/Apl 6.62 July/Aug. 6.10 Nov/Dec. 5.68

north-east No. 2 winze was deepened 9 ft, total depth 102 ft; the vein, 8 ins wide, dwt 7 grs per ton. 350 ft south-west level was advanced 14 ft total distance 403 ft ; vein averaged 17 ins wide, worth 15 dwts per ton 245 ft level north-east was advanced 12 ft, total distance 300 ft; the quartz averaged 14 ins wide, and 3 dwts 6 grs per ton in value. 245 ft south-west level was advanced 12 ft to a distance of 431 ft ; the vein averaged 14 ins wide and 6 dwts 12 grs per ton in value. 245 ft raise at 15 ft north-east risen 8 ft ; the quartz 87 ins wide, assayed 1 oz 19 dwts 20 grs per ton. In a stope above this level the quartz is 23 ins wide, assaying 1 oe 0 dwts 21 grs per ton. In two stopes below this level the quartz, 21 ins and 18 ins wide, assayed for 0 dwt 22 grs and 9 dwts 3 grs respectively. Western shaft was deepened 10ft, total depth 298ft: is at present in dyke; last sample on junction of dyke assay ed 2 ozs 1 dwt 19 grs over 24 ins of quartz 270 ft level north-east was driven 12 ft ; quartz 20 ins wide was worth 5 dwts 5 grs per ton. 270 ft level south-west has been driven 3ft; quartz 23 ins wide, assays a trace of gold."

div.head: PROSPECTUS.
div.p: This company was formed in December, 1897, for the purpose of acquiring the business of Messrs. Walker & Co., of Cairo, as from the 1st May, 1897, and that of Messrs. C. G. Meimarachi & Co., of Cairo, as from 1st July 1987.

The original capital of the Company was £250,000, divided into 25,000 6 1/2 per cent. Preference Shares of £5 each, and 25,OOQ Ordinary Shares of £5 each, of which latter only 15,000 shares were issued. The Company has recently passed the necessary resolutions for increasing the capital to £400,000 and for converting all the Shares into Shares of £1 each.

Messrs. Walker & Meimarachi, Ltd., is now the most important business of its kind in Egypt as Army Contractors, Wide and Spirit Merchants, Provision Dealers, Drapers, Milliners, and Silk and General Merchants, having important Agencies and Sub Agencies for a large number of the principal leading English, French, German, Italian, and Austrian manufacturing houses doing business in Egypt.

The financial prosperity of Egypt during the last few years has improved beyond all anticipation, and its continuance is regarded as an established fact. Of recent years the agriculture of the country has developed, railways have been completed, districts hitherto inaccessible to trade have been opened up, and insignificant villages in a few years have developed into prosperous and thriving. Towns, with the result that the purchasing power of the ever increasing population has led to a growing demand for European manufactures and commodities.

Owing to the extensive business experience and influence of its Executive in Egypt, the Company is in a position to continue to command an increasing volume in every department of native and European trade.

Owing to the recent development in trade in Egypt, the Company's premises were found to be inadequate to cope with the growth of its business. Daring the last few years the centre of the trade of Cairo has changed, and what was convenient at the time of the formation of the Company has recently become unsuited to its customers. The Directors, realising the necessity for meeting their altered conditions, have purchased certain land situate in the fashionable Ismailieh quarter of Cairo.

The purchase price of the property is L.E. 72.247.800 and the report of Mr. Henry Hinks (Messrs. Barclay Hinks & Co. Cairo, a member of the Surveyors Institution, London dated the 16th of January 1906, in respect to its value when acquired and present value is as follows.
"I have made an inspection of the property lately purchased by you at the junction of Charia El Manakh and Charia El Madabegh in the Ismailiheh quarter of Cairo at the price of L.B. 72,247.

"The property is of an area of 4816.5 square metres, of a rectangular shape, and through its central position in the European business and residential quarter, it undoubtedly provides one of the finest and most suitable sites in Cairo for the erection of your new buildings.
"In my opinion the present value of this property is ninety six thousand, three hundred and thirty pounds Egyptian (L.E. 96330) or £2o per square metre.

"This amount greatly exceeds your purchase price ; the value of land in this quarter is still rising, and a further increase may be expected should the new Bourse be erected, as is intended, on a site in the immediate vicinity."

The Directors have arranged with Nungovich Bey for placing £100,000 5 per cent. Mortgage Debentures and the amount produced from these Debentures and the present issue (which has already been guaranteed by Nungovich Bey) will provide the necessary fonds for the purchase of the land and the erection of suitable buildings thereon, in addition to providing further working capital for the Company.

No deferred Shares have been issued, and after payment of the Preference Dividend amounting to £8,125 per annum. provision for Interest on Debentures reserve, depreciation, etc., the balance of profit is available for dividend to the holders of ordinary Shares.

Perusual of the following returns based upon the Company's published accounts and Balance Sheets, only certified by Messrs. W. B. Peat & Co., Chartered Accountants, of London, serve to show the soundness and progressive nature of the Company's trading since its incorporation to the date of the last published Balance Sheet to 30th April, 1905, and there is every reason to anticipate even more satisfactory progress in the future.
The Net Profits of Trading after deducting cost of management in Egypt have been as fellows: —
<table>
The total amount written off Goodwill, Fixtures and Fittings, Preliminary Expenses, etc., has amounted to £30,499.3. 8.
The Reserve Find amounts to £5 451. 8, 10.
The dividends distributed on the ordinary shares during the past three years have been as follows :
For the 12 months ending 30th April, 1903, at the rate of 8 per rent. £2,250. 0.0.
„ 30th April, 1904, 4 per cent. £3,000 0.0.
At the 30th April, 1905, the amount carried forward was £3,339. 0.

A Contract dated the 13th of January 1906 has been entered into between the Company and George Nungovich Bey, whereby the latter has agreed to subscribe for or procure subscriptions for the whole or such part of the present issue of 100,000 Ordinary Shares as have not been applied for within a fixed period in consideration of which the Company has agreed to pay him by way of commission, the sum of £10 000. By this contract an earlier contract between the same parties dated the 20th of May 1905 and another contract in the form of a letter from G. Nungovich Bey to the Company dated the 19th of September 1905 were rescinded.

A Contract dated the 13th of January 1906 has been entered into between the Company and George Nungovich Bey, whereby the latter, in consideration of his subscribing for £100,000 5 per cent. Mortgage Debentures at 90 per cent, redeemable at par at the expiration of 60 years or earlier on six months' notice by the Company, was granted an option to subscribe at par for the balance of the Company's unissued shares for a fixed period.
The following contracts relate to the purchase by the Company of the before mentioned land :

A contract dated the 13th of November 1905 between the Egyptian Estates Limited of the one part and Constantin George Meimarachi of Cairo of the other part by which the latter purchased the same for LE. 72,247,BOO.

A contract dated the 13th of January 1906 between the said Constantin George Meimarachi of the first part; the Egyptian Estates Limited of the second, part and the Company of the third part by which Mr. Meimarachi made over to the Company all his rights under the last mentioned contract for the price therein stated.
Various sub-underwriting Contracts have been entered into by George Nungovich Bey.

Some of the present Shareholders having represented to the Directors that they were anxious to participate in the present issue, it has been decided to allow the existing Shareholders to apply for Shares of the present issue pro rata to the amount of their holding, and application from such Shareholders will receive a preference over other applicants.
The present issue having been guaranteed, as above mentioned the Directors will only go to allotment on the whole of the issue.
On the 16th of December, 1897, 25.000 preference shares of £5 each were offered for subscription, and the whole of these shares were allotted and have been paid up in full.
On the formation of the Company 15,000 ordinary shares of £5 each were issued as fully paid as the purchase consideration for the two businesses above mentioned.

Copies of the above contracts, the Memorandum and Articles of Association, and the Balance Sheets, containing the certificates of Messrs. W. B. Peat & Co., can be inspected by intending subscribers during the time the lists are open, at the offices of the Company in London.
Application will be made in due course for a settlement and official quotation on the London Stock Exchange.
Application for shares must be made on the accompanying form and forwarded to the Company's Bankers, together with a remittance for the amount of the deposit.
Share Warrants to Bearer in denominations of 5, 25 and 50 shares will be issued in respect of Fully Paid Shares to any shareholders desiring same free of cost.

If no allotment be made the deposit will be returned in full, and if only a portion of the amount applied for be allotted the balance of the deposit will be applied towards the payment due on allotment.
Failure to pay any of the instalments or calls at due date will render all previous payments liable to forfeiture.
The prospectuses and forms of application may be obtained from the Company's Bankers, and at the offices of the Company in London, Paris, Manchester and Egypt
London. 25 January 1906

div.head: NOTICE.
Khartoum Province Tramways.
div.p: The Governor of Khartoum Province invites tenders for supplying the following materials :— About 7,000 metres of rails with sleepers, fish-plates, clips, and bolts.
Nine (9) Switch points.
Ten (10) Cars.
One (1) Water tank.
One (1) Force Pump.
One (1) Locomotive turntable.
Specifications and conditions for tender can be seen at the Sudan Agent's Office, Cairo, any day (Friday and general holidays excepted), between 10 a.m. and 1 p.m.
Tenders should be submitted by February 25th, 1906, addressed to Governor of Khartoum, Khartoum, and most include delivery at Khartoum via Port Sudan, Customs charges excluded.
The Governor of Khartoum does not bind himself to accept the lowest or any tender.
(Signed) E. A. STANTON, Miralai, Governor of Khartoum Province.

div.head: MINISTRY OF INTERIOR
DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH.
NOTICE.
div.p: In a notice headed "The National Hotel, Cairo" the following is published :
"The sanitary arrangements have been designed and carried out by English engineers and under the direct supervision of the Government."
The above statement is quite incorrect as neither the plans of the building nor those of the sanitary arrangements have been submitted to the Department of Public Health for approval. 27246-1

div.head: CHRONIQUE JUDICIAIRE
Affaires du Mariout
div.p: La Gouvernement vient de sommer un grand nombre de soi-disant propriétaires da Miriout d'avoir dans les hait joarsds la signifioati in, à quieter le s terrains qu'ils ont usurpés au Gouvernement.

La prétendue possession, dont les usurpateurs 8emb eut se prévaloir, ôomme mode d'acquisition, par les vendeurs, de la propriété des dits terrai as, aurait dans tous les oas et eu toute hypothèse, les caraotères d'une occupation précaire, toléréa p$r le Gouvernement ; élis ne présenterait ni laoontiauité, ni I'animus do mini, exigés par la loi, pour qu'elle puisse servir de base à la prescription acquisitive.

A défaut de titre on de prescriptions con trairas de la part des vendeurs et, par suite, de leurs ayant-droit, l'Etat doit être oonsidéré comme le véritable propriétaire. Dans son aote introductif d'instanoe le Gouvernement demande que les actes de ventes Boient déclarés nuis et de nul effet ; entendre ordonner, en conséquence; que sur simple présentation du jugement à intervenir, M. le Greffier du Tribunal Mixte d'Alexandrie soit tenu d'opérer la radiation de la transcription du dit contrat de vente.
S'entendre de même suite condamner à payer pour indue occupation des dommages'intérêts à libeller par état et par instanoe séparés..

div.p: (Le mouvement à la hausse se dessine de plus en plus,, eu particulier auKks banques. Un grand nombre de transactions ont été effectuées en Banque Nationale, Agricole, EstàtesTTrust et Markets. J De 26 la National fait un bond à 26 9/16. L'Agricole monte aussi à 9 23/32, l'Obligation GÿéJit Foncier à 331, la Banque d'Athèaes à 137 1/2, U Land Bauk à 8 l/l6, et la Cassa di Soonto à 203 1/2.

L'Union Fonoière continue à avanoor de 5 15/L6 à 6 et la Wardan de 6 1/4 à 6 3/8.
£*a hausse également les Markets à 25, la Sa)t& Soda à 22/4$, la Nungovioh à 13 1/8 et la Delta Light à 11 7/16.
Le reste de la cote demeure stationnaire, .mais en bonne tendanca

Cette tenue exceptionnellement bonne de notre marché au moment de la liquidation de fin du mois est déterminée en partie par la fermeté des marchés de Londres et de Paris et en partie par le niveau peu élevé des oours.
'Hassan Pacha Assem vient d'aoheter de la famille El Darsmalli pour le compte del'Anglo Egyptian Land Allottment 1,180 fiddans sis à Menchiet El Ibrahimieh pour le prix de L.E. 64,000.

NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: Hier, à Londres, le Consolidé'anglai* a haussé de 3/8 à 90 3/8. Par contre, l'Unifiéo a baisté de 1/4 à 104 r /4. La National Bank est restée invariée 4 25 3/4, de même qne la Daïra à 17 ft. L'Agricole a gagné 1/8 à 9 6/8.
A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier et la Banque d'Athènes ont olôturé, inohangées, à 800 et 135.
Ici, ce matin, le marohé des valeurs a été assez animé, avec tendance géuéralement fermé.

La National Bank et l'Agricole, sur lesquelles il y a eu de nombreuses transactions, ont clôturé, la première à 2 S 15 16 et la seconde à 9 9/16, après avoir atteint 5/8. La Banque d'Athènes a avancé h 137; le Comptoir Financier à 411/16 L'action Crédit Foncier est restée à 802-803.

Toujours mouvementées, les parts de jouissance Eaux du Caire ont monté à 270. L'aotion Agricole du Nil a progressé à 245 et la part de fondateur * 4 3/8. Le Cardan Eitate a avancé à 6 3/8 et l'Union Fonoière à 5 15/16.

Dftns le groupe des Hôtels, les Nungovich t-e font inscrits à i3 1/16, les Baehler à 4 1/4, les Upper Egypt à 5 1/4 et les Anglo-American Nile à 5 9/16-5/8. Il y a eu aussi que'ques transactions en Splendid Hotels.
Parmi les petites valeurs, le; Glymenoifoulo,
en bonne tendanoe, ont olôturé À 11/4, les Sait
and Soda à 21 uh. 9, les Markets à 24 sh. 3 et
les Cotton Mills à 6 sh.
Nous avons signalé hier, sous réserve, la rumeur qui oourait au sujet d'une nouvelle
émission d'actions de la Nnngovioh Hotels Co.

Or, c'é'ait, paralt-iî, un faux bruit Ua ad mimstratenr nous dit, en tflit, qu'il n'a jamais été question de oela. L* dernière émission a suffi amplement aux besoins de la Société et il n'y a auoune raison d'augmenter le capital*

L'assemblée générale ordinaire des 4£V5nnaires du Crédit Foncier Bgyptien a étlLmue cet après-midi, h 3 heures, au siège social au Caire. Le dividende pour l'exeioioe 1905 a été fixé à 15 francs par action, oomme nous l'avions, d'ailleurs, annoncé il y a quelque temps, et b 171 françé par part de fondateur.

L'assemblée générale ordinaire de l'Alexan dria and Ramleh Railway Co., qui s'est tenue avant-hier à A lexandrie,a approuvé à l'unanimité le rapport du conseil, ainsi que les oQmptes de l'exmcice 1904 1905 En conséquence, le diviv dende de cet exercice a été fixé à 3 sh. 6 pa> action de £ 1 nominale, ce qui représente du 17 ft pour cent.

M. Periclès Qlymenopoulo, administrateur de l'Egyptian Trust and Investment, a été élu administrateur de la Société, en remplacera nt de M. Ambroise Zervudaohi, qui s'est retiré en raison de «es nombreuses oooupationi,
"The Egyptian Gazette" rapporte à oe propo
que le baron de Ensel bey, direotenr-général
de l'Egyptian Trust and Investment fera par
tie, de son cô é, du oonseil d'administration de
l'Alexandria Tramways Co. Suivant la "Gazette'
cp8 nominations tendraient à confirmer les ru
men s d'après lesquelles le Trm-t serait large
ment intéressé dans les Tramways d'Alexandrie. •

Les actionnaires de l'Egyptian Improvements Corporation sont convoqués en assemblée ex traordinaire pour le 17 février proohain, à l'effet de délibérer sur les propositions suivantes du conseil d'administration :
1° Clôture du premier exeroioe sooial an 81 décembre 19 '5 en dérogation de l'artiole 3 8 des Statuts; 2° Augmentation du capital aotions; V* Création d'nn oapital obligations.
Dans le oas où oes propositions seraient acceptées, laréanion serait immé liatement suivie d'une assemblée ordinaire, aveo l'ordre da jour oi-après :
Lecture du rapport da oonseil et da rapport des censeurs ; approbation des oomptes et fixation du dividende poor l'exercice 1905, eto.
Les oonrs du ooton arriveut en petite reprise d'Amérique. L'Octobre a gagné hier 6 points et le Mai 1 point. Le disponible est resté inva-rié à 11.50.
Les arrivages ont été de 30,000 balles contre 41,000.
Le marohé de Liverpool est en légère réaotion.
loi, le Mars a ouvert, ce matin, à 16 5/8
pour olôturer à 16 9/16.

On nous oftble de Liverpool que, suivant les derniers avis de New-York, la position est oon-sidérée oomme s'étaut fortement améliorée ; on croit que le marohé se trouve actuellement dans de bonnes oondirions. Les difficultés concernant la liquidation semblent avoir été surmontées. _
